meeting_annotations.speaker: Dave Durgan
meeting_annotations.transcript: Uh that's going to be like the first cut. But but yeah, each subsequent dilution uh the abundances are definitely changing.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Judith Eisen

meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, in terms of in terms of gene expression, yes. And you know, it's not been studied functionally very well, very well. meeting_annotations.speaker: Erin Longbrake
meeting_annotations.transcript: One thing that hasn't really come up and we've talked a lot about kind of direct interactions between these bacterial metabolites and nerves and neurons. meeting_annotations.transcript: No, I think it's a great point and that really kind of helps us to get around this problem that we've been bringing up of concentrations, right? meeting_annotations.speaker: Judith Eisen
meeting_annotations.transcript: It can also be through uh cytokine receptors that are expressed in the CNS that respond to cytokines that will be secreted by different immune cells.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Robin Voigt
meeting_annotations.transcript: For a long time it was even thought that the brain was, you know, separate from the peripheral immune system, but we know that that's not true anymore. meeting_annotations.transcript: I mean guess one one difficult question is always with that like Erin what you're bringing up of you know, potentially mobile cells being educated in the gut and changing their behavior and then going more central. meeting_annotations.speaker: Erin Longbrake
meeting_annotations.transcript: Can I add? I mean, you're right. I mean, but in a sense isn't that what the whole endocrine system is? That you have distant responses. So you're right. meeting_annotations.speaker: JP Yu
meeting_annotations.transcript: To take Noah's theological question to the next step, the one thing that I've always wondered is why the heck do we even have gut microbes living essentially inside of us? meeting_annotations.speaker: Judith Eisen
meeting_annotations.transcript: Oh, they do a lot of really great things.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Robin Voigt
meeting_annotations.transcript: They actually create vitamins that we can't synthesize on our own. Um, it's a symbiotic relation. We get we get stuff out of it too, for sure.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Judith Eisen
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think that's

meeting_annotations.speaker: Noah Palm
meeting_annotations.transcript: I actually totally so I have a strong strong opinion about this which I totally disagree with the idea that any of these things are symbionts.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Noah Palm
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, I I think we have bugs in our guts for well and on us and wherever for for two reasons. Um, well the most basic reason is because it's impossible to avoid. Bacteria are everywhere and we were going to have something there. Um, because the cost of keeping it sterile was probably too high. Um, you know, the the costs of having that constant immune response and the the uh, you know, the collateral damage of those ongoing responses to maintain truce sterility was too high.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Noah Palm
meeting_annotations.transcript: And so then what we chose to do is actually harbor organisms that are the least bad for us, right? meeting_annotations.transcript: Now that creates um a new condition on top of which uh uh dependencies can evolve, right?
